lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a story and identify key characters and animal toys mentioned.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say: “Listen for rabbit, toy, fox.” Play story audio. Students raise hand when they hear one of the key words.
stretchStrategies: "Rewrite the Ending" – Students change the ending of the story using simple sentences and act it out in small groups using animal props or flashcards.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story aloud, act it out, and answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Read story aloud with roles. Students echo key lines and act them out using gestures and toy flashcards.
stretchStrategies: "Rewrite the Ending" – Students change the ending of the story using simple sentences and act it out in small groups using animal props or flashcards.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can create a simple, imaginative ending to the story by drawing or acting it out.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Show last page of the story. Ask: “What happens next?” Students draw or role-play their imagined ending.
stretchStrategies: "Rewrite the Ending" – Students change the ending of the story using simple sentences and act it out in small groups using animal props or flashcards.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.

languageTransferAnalysis.section: 4. Plural forms of it is and there is:
items: Plural forms of these structures do not exist in Vietnamese. It's difficult for kids to remember to produce them, particularly because the plural element comes before the noun phrase. There are two houses
